Award.AwardTitle: IBSS: The Spread and Impact of Moral Messages: Machine Learning, Network Evolution, and Behavioral Prediction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
In the immediate aftermath of the 2013 Boston Marathon tragedy, hundreds of thousands of prosocial acts were evident on social media, such as reposted links for blood donation sites, information regarding how to get in touch with loved ones, and even offers to provide food and shelter for those in need. Far from isolated acts, these behaviors occurred within social networks, amid shared moral messages of empathy and solidarity. This interdisciplinary research project will examine how people respond to public crises and how moral reactions shape these responses in social networks. The project will contribute new theoretical insights and methodological advances in moral psychology, network sociology, computer science, and other fields. It will enhance understanding of how moral concerns spread through social networks and explore new theoretical frameworks dealing with human moral decision making and group dynamics. These theoretical frameworks will guide the development of artificial intelligence techniques for building descriptive models of morality, and the new methods of sentiment analysis and machine learning will be used to assess theoretical models of moral concerns and social influence in networks. By examining factors influencing the spread of moral messages and participation in prosocial activities, such as charitable giving, the project may help increase the well-being of individuals in emergency situations. The project also will facilitate future inquiry into how the public and persistent nature of social media may provide new ways to understand and forecast social change.

The interdisciplinary science of morality has developed well-validated measures of moral concerns using a number of different approaches, such as Moral Foundations Theory and Schwartz's Values Circumplex. Empirical research in this field usually has assessed moral judgments via questionnaires gathering information well after actions have occurred, however. Sociology has done more to assess behavior as it occurs but has used even more limited measures. Recent innovations in computer science offer new ways to gather information about the structure of moral judgments and large-scale behavior in natural settings as well as the relationships between the two. The investigators will employ these new computer-based methods to examine texts from social media in order to examine the structure of moral concerns and values without relying on preset questionnaires. They will investigate the network dynamics of the spread of moral messages and behaviors, and they will determine how moral content in social media can predict real-world behavior at both individual and societal scales. The investigators will couple machine learning and sentiment analysis techniques with theories about moral cognition and social dynamics. Among questions they will pursue are how well everyday moral judgments (made without researcher prompting) correspond with dominant psychological theories of morality and whether it is possible to model and predict how moral influence can lead to subsequent prosocial or antisocial behavior. This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Societal problems – and their solutions – can often be attributed to two simple facts: people act prosocially, and people act antisocially. These behaviors often depend on moral visions of the world and social networks to transmit them. How do moral concerns spread throughout networks and motivate behavior? Our team took an interdisciplinary approach to try to answer these questions. Specifically, for the past three years we had researchers from moral psychology, network sociology, and computer science use a verity of methods and models to get us closer to answering this question. In summary, our work in this project started a new line of research for studying morality indirectly using observational social media studies, complemented with confirmatory behavioral experiments. We also made several methodological contributions to the field, enabling a more thorough and precise analyses of textual data for socio-psychological research.

 

For example, we investigated whether sharing moral values encourages people to connect and form communities (Dehghani et al., 2016). Using both social-media analysis and behavioral experiments, we investigated which types of moral similarities pull people together, or push them away from each other. Performing a large-scale analysis of tweets revealed that social network processes reflect moral selection, and both online and offline differences in moral purity concerns are particularly predictive of social distance.

 

In another line of work, we investigated whether appeals to moral values promote charitable donation during natural disasters (Hoover et al., 2017). Again, we approached this question using a combination of social media analysis study, and confirmatory behavioral experiments. Specifically, we first analyzed tweets posted during Hurricane Sandy to explore associations between moral values and charitable donation sentiment. We then tested whether the observed associations could be replicated across a series of preregistered experiments that investigate the effects of moral framing on perceived donation motivation, hypothetical donation, and real donation behavior. Overall, we find consistent positive associations between moral care and loyalty framing with donation sentiment and donation motivation.

 

As part of this project, we made several methodological contributions as well. For example, we introduced Distributed Dictionary Representations (DDR), a method that applies psychological dictionaries using semantic similarity rather than word counts (Garten et al., 2017). This allows for the measurement of the similarity between dictionaries and spans of text ranging from complete documents to individual words. In a different line of work, we introduced ConversAtion level Syntax SImilarity Metric (CASSIM), a novel method for calculating conversation-level syntax similarity (Boghrati et al., 2017). CASSIM estimates the syntax similarity between conversations by automatically generating syntactical representations of the sentences in conversation, estimating the structural differences between them, and calculating an optimized estimate of the conversation-level syntax similarity. Lastly, we introduced and demonstrated a methodological framework for testing the importance of contextual information in inferring speaker intentions from text (Garten et al., 2019). In this work, we applied Long Short-term Memory networks, a standard for representing language in its natural, sequential state, and conducted a set of experiments for predicting the persuasive intentions of speakers in debates using different combinations of text and background information about the speaker.
